Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2012 03:30PM LouiseBogle wrote: Hi Ann, I have total respect for people who can go through this and work! I have treatment about once a month, I write off 7-10 days and then fill my time with as much tennis and as little housework as I can! A few coffee mornings, trips to garden centres, family duties etc and I'm flat out b4 kids get in at 14.30. Then it's homework and after school activities. I wonder how I ever managed to fit work in. I would love my old job but it's just not feasible with the amount of time I need for hospital appointments and for getting over chemo symptoms. I don't spend all my time thinking about cancer and personally I love playing tennis, going to yoga etc..if you decided to give up work my advice would be to work at not working. It takes time (and I loved my job) but you can find a new routine and enjoy it too. Good luck with whatever choice you make x
Posts.Title: Working for a living....taking what they're giving... CoolBreeze Linda1966

Posts.Content: LouiseBogle wrote: I had chemo last Wednesday and today I was back to see the doc. Despite having a neulasta shot, turns out I'm neutrpenic. So far so good in that I'm not sick but having spent the past 8 days staring at the walls of my house I'm feeling ready to go places, and do things. So what do I do? Stay at home and construct a large wall to keep all germs out, or just get on with it?! If I didn't know, I'd just be getting on with things but now I do..... Posts.Title: Would this be ok? katie31 Padiddle

Posts.Content: LouiseBogle wrote: I got results of a ct scan today and unfortunately my vinoralbine (navelbine) regime is either losing or has lost it's efficiency. I was diagnosed with a spread to the liver in December 2010 following surgery, but this is the first confirmation from imaging. Up to this point it had stayed small enough not to be seen. From next week I start on CMF. Any of you lovely ladies had success with this? Doesn't matter how well you prepare yourself, those bad scan results are so hard to deal with. Hopefully this is the one that gets me to stable or even better NED. My little girl makes her first holy communion next May and I just need to be there! Dx 12/7/2010, ER+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

CMF is a combination of chemo drugs called cyclophosphamide, methotrexate & 5 fluorouracil. I'm in Ireland so it could be that they operate under different brand names in other countries?

Posts.Title: My onc speaks in riddles! LouiseBogle pminxy

Posts.Content: LouiseBogle wrote: Anyone else have this problem? I've been seeing (it's ok my hubbie knows!) my onc for over 5 years and I think we've probably got too familiar. He's about my age, has kids my age and lives near me. I think he genuinely likes me and as a result talks in riddles rather than telling me the hard truth! Sometimes I want to know the full details and other times I don't, I watch him trying to interpret me while I do the same with him (my hubbie looks on watching me watching him watching me!). Yesterday for example I got a bad scan result with progression in the liver, almost as I was walking out the door, and only when I asked about other organs did I find out that I had a small area of fluid in one lung sac. Does this mean I have pleural effusion? I start a new chemo, myocet which is doxirubicon in the next week or so. Help what does this mean?! Will I be ok? Despite the scans I am strong and do some form of physical activity most days and still don't think I look like I'm ill. I also cook, clean, wash iron and deliver two children with great social lives here there and everywhere every day!! Hope some of you wise girls can help. Dx 12/7/2010, ER+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2011 12:09PM LouiseBogle wrote: Hi Jennifer, I am new to this site and like you have bone and liver mets. I have been on navelbine since December and after my first one I ended up in hospital with an infection and v low WBC. The next cycle they put me on neupogen for 5 days and like you got the most horrific pain. Since then I've been on neupogen for 3 days and that's been enough to keep me infection free and without major pain. Between chemo, zometa, neupogen and tamoxifen I don't know what causes the pains these days! Take care of yourself. Louise

Posts.Title: Beautiful Saturday CoolBreeze Gtiger

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 10:40PM LouiseBogle wrote: I came across this site when like Laurie, I was searching for information on liver mets. That was 13 months ago. I was and still am I suppose, completely devastated by my diagnosis. We were married for 5 years before we had the kids and I love them so much I feel my heart could break (a son age 10 and a daughter age 8) Coming to terms with not being part of their future is the hardest part for me. Being on this site has helped me with that and has really helped me to focus on the here and now. I am also heartened by the stories of survival and longevity. God I sound like a really depressing character! I live a relatively normal life (aside from almost weekly hospital appointments) and so far being sick, hasn't got me out of ironing, cooking, cleaning or any other domestic duties! I was a sales director for a large media company but I quit when I was diagnosed and I'm really glad I did. Money is tight but the lack of stress and time to indulge in tennis, yoga and baking more than compensates. My favorite thing about this site is the great knowledge and support you get from people who really know what it's like.

Posts.Content: LouiseBogle wrote: Girls, apologies about not being able to include a link, but I'm working from an iPad and I don't know how to do it! Last week I read the most amazing article in the Irish Times. It's got nothing to do with breast cancer but the themes in the article are relevant to all of us. It is about a young film maker called Simon Fitzmaurice who was diagnosed with motor neurone diesese. As I read it, tears rolled down my cheeks, but it is hugely inspirational and incredibly positive. It has generated quite a response here in Ireland . To me, it's the writers strong understanding of himself, his emotions and the power of the spiritual side of well being, that makes it such essential reading. I'd you go to www.irishtimes.com and search for either Simon Fitzmaurice or Motor neurone. The headline for the article is 'that's the thing about your death, it pulls in all you loved ones'. It was published on 5th December. Hope you can find it x Dx 12/7/2010, ER+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2011 02:46PM LouiseBogle wrote: Hi Angela, I was diagnosed with bone mets in April 2010 and liver mets in December. I did navelbine and zometa until recently but my scan at the beginning of this month showed progression in the liver so I'm on a treatment called cmf (it's got a different name in the States) which is 'old school' but supposed to be effective. I've tolerated all chemo quite well including cmf shush I only started last Thur. My onc doesn't give me tm's thank god but assures me there are lots of other chemo options still available for me. I'm sure it will be the same for you. Hope you do really well, take care x

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2012 05:21AM LouiseBogle wrote: Hi Saeed, first of all I'm sorry that your mum and your family are having to go through this. However you should be assured that there are treatment options and some of the other girls with a similar diagnosis will post and let you know how they are doing. I have been living with bone mets for almost 24 months and liver mets for 13. Ive just started my 3rd chemo and apart from some side effects from the chemo, I've definitely been living for the past two years! My son is only 10 but I think age is irrelevant, we all want to love and be loved. You never stop being a mum so I'm sure your mum will point you in the right direction. As much as you want to do things for your mum I guarantee she is still going to be watching out for you! Take care and I hope your mum heals quickly and gets started on a treatment that will knock the cancer out!

I've used the Emmend the last couple of times, and I think it probably is a better option than the steroids. Thankfully the cost of the drug is not an issue in Ireland and you can get most things you need. Thanks for the feedback girls, skipping the oral dex worked out ok for me, hope you all get relief from your anti nausea meds of choice!

Posts.Content: LouiseBogle wrote: Hi girls, just wanted to say that this time 12 months ago I was so upset. It was my birthday and I'd just found out that my stage four cancer was not just in my spine but also in my liver. I was devastated. Now a year later it's my birthday again, and even though I've been on non stop chemo, I feel grand. I know I'm a relative newbie, but I'm symptom free, and I've had a great day! I'm having a glass of champagne and raising a toast to all the great girls on this site who made me believe that this birthday and many more are possible. Thanks girls, you are a great bunch! Dx 12/7/2010, ER+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: It's my birthday LouiseBogle eag1954

Posts.Content: May 29, 2012 11:33PM LouiseBogle wrote: Take care Apple x
Posts.Title: it's always something apple K-Lo

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2012 04:36PM LouiseBogle wrote: I have mets to my spine (and my liver !) and since my diagnosis in Apr 2010, the mets haven't caused me any major issues. I had some radiotherapy for pain but otherwise, I've been able to play tennis and keep up my yoga. I'm not very good at either of them, but God loves a trier! I've been on Zometa every 4 weeks for the past two years. Hope your mets don't restrict the things you like doing x
Posts.Title: anyone else have mets to spine? nikibird SusanR

Posts.Content: LouiseBogle wrote: I'm confused and need some guidance from the wise girls on this board. I saw three onc nurses today when I went for my first myocet chemo . Each of them asked me if I had enough anti sickness meds. I told them all I didn't want to take the steroids as they make me v bloated and give me a bright red face! They both said it was fine and that most people tolerated the myocet ok. Third nurse was full of the horrors and said she was pretty sure I'd be sick and I should take the steroids as they are one of the best anti-nausea meds. What do you think I should do? Myocet is part of the doxirubicon family, bright red fluorescent coloured chemo! Dx 12/7/2010, ER+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Dexamethosone or not? LouiseBogle LouiseBogle

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2011 11:18AM LouiseBogle wrote: It was a pulmonary embolism for me that lead to a bone met diagnosis. The pain from the PE was almost exactly the same as the pain to the thoracic spine. Really strange, like my body used one thing to point out another. Radiation sorted out that pain. You have been through the mill already, hopefully the Pet scan results will be good for you. Take care
Posts.Title: Cracked Rib Robin75 Robin75

Posts.Content: LouiseBogle wrote: Hoping someone can help. I have only ever had a bone scan or CT scan. Am I missing out on anything (ie more mets) by not having had a pet scan? My hospital doesn't have this type of scanner but I could get it done somewhere else as I have good health insurance. Appreciate anyone's input, I'm a newcomer to this site and really appreciate the well of support that exists here. Dx 12/7/2010, ER+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Pet scans LouiseBogle jloon

Posts.Content: May 31, 2012 07:34AM LouiseBogle wrote: Hi Katie, Missed this post with hospital appointments etc but hope you had a great day, loads of cake and the sun was shining. When I was diagnosed in 2010 with liver mets, i was sure I wouldn't make Luke's Communion and contemplated pulling Millie out of her class so she could prepare with him. Well he made his last year, she made hers two weeks ago. Everyone said she looked fab and that I did too. Friends I haven't seen in a few months came by and couldn't believe I looked as well as I did (that sounds so vain, I'm not like that at all!) Bit of a Cinderella moment when I removed the hair piece, took off the carefully applied make-up, realised the nails were chipped and the fake tan was coming off in patches but only my poor family had to c that transformation!! I suppose I'm just saying between one year and the next, I had my ups and downs but I made it and most of the time I was well and happy. Our oncologists are heading to Chicago this week so hopefully they will come pack with armfuls of treatments and plans to keep us all in good shape so we can do all the things we want with our families. Enjoy the pure loveliness of your 4 year old, I have an almost 9 year old who thinks she's 19, everything's for babies and wants me to buy her cool clothes because I know nothing about fashion! Take care x
Posts.Title: My daughter is 4 tomorrow katie31 apple

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2012 05:00PM LouiseBogle wrote: I hate the hair thing too. Mine has thinned incredibly and it really upsets me. I hope you find a great wig, scarf or even both and they make you feel better. Hair or no hair, you are super smart, honest, witty and great with words. I love reading your posts and you've certainly helped me out. Take care x
Posts.Title: Bald again CoolBreeze JillThut

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2011 11:18AM LouiseBogle wrote: Don't give up hope, I have liver and bone mets and navelbine stopped working for me after 10 cycles which was about 9/10 months. Now I'm on CMF, had cycle two last week and will be scanned after cycle 3. The thing is my oncologist says I have lots of other options including trials. It's crap when things progress but that doesn't mean it's over! Get another opinion soon. I'm sure some of the more experienced girls have loads more to offer, their stories made me believe that progression is only a stumbling block onto a different road. Take care x
Posts.Title: Navelbine Failed Liver Mets 4everhopeful Priscilla0929

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2011 07:38AM LouiseBogle wrote: Thanks girls, I was afraid I was missing out on something by not having a pet scan. I'm stage 4 with mets to spine (many places) and liver. The liver was only dx'ed in Dec 2010 after an op to remove my ovaries. I've been on vinorelbine ever since, had my 10th cycle this week.

Posts.Title: Sunshine after the storm cmhartley Honeybear

Posts.Content: May 13, 2012 04:08PM LouiseBogle wrote: I get it too, now 43 and 2 years into stage 4, my kids are 8 and 10. I want to help them become good adults, achieve their dreams, have as many experiences as possible and make sure they eat 5 portions of fruit and veg a day! Can't bloody do it if I'm not here.
Posts.Title: No, you don't understand... Stormynyte Reneepals

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2012 04:12PM LouiseBogle wrote: Formygirls, This is the most terrifying time for you but please be reassured by all the great girls on this site. It takes time to come to terms with this diagnosis but you will and you do have treatment options. I have bone mets since April 2010 and liver mets since Dec 2010. I was distraught and worried about my two lovely kids but you know, I'm on my third chemo, I've had progression but I'm very much alive and well. Tonight me and my hubbie payed in our first ever tennis tournament, we had a great time (didn't win!) and I'm really hoping I'll be playing this time next year and the one after that. Life continues and yours will to. Let your onc know that you are ready to do whatever it takes and do it!! Sending you hugs and as much positive light as I can xx
Posts.Title: HELP. Just diagnosed today--lung, liver and bone mets formygirls Heidihill
